description: {"blocks":[{"key":"63s5o","text":"Focussing on the role of contact materials as an element of variable control in archaeological use-wear experiments, this protocol sets out a workflow for the preparation, use and documentation of standardized beechwood contact samples. Although developed in the context of rig-based experimentation with bronze axe replicas as part of MAP, it follows principles and sets out procedures of broader applicability within traceological experimental research in general and in studies involving ligneous contact material in particular.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":336,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5ok5","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ki60","text":"MAP (the Mainz, Mayen \u0026 Monrepos Axperimental Programme) expands into a 'post-lithic' material class (copper-based artefacts) and chronological setting (the Bronze Age) the research agenda developed by TraCEr, which is based on a strong commitment to open science and an understanding of sustained methodological development as a key to consolidating traceology as a sub-discipline within archaeology.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":9,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":16,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":24,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":33,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":46,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79o08","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1voje","text":"TraCEr (the Laboratory for Traceology and Controlled Experiments) was established by the RGZM, the Leibniz Research Institute for Archaeology, at the MONREPOS Research Centre and Museum at Neuwied in 2017. Its main scope is to carry out ground-breaking research that combines methodological development, aided by state-of-the-art facilities for controlled experimentation and advanced methods of documentation, and fundamental research on Pleistocene and Early Holocene archaeology.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":27,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":42,"length":1},{"style":"bold","offset":53,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":6},{"key":1,"offset":89,"length":4},{"key":2,"offset":150,"length":8}],"data":{}},{"key":"6nvp4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e7b0k","text":" plank of high-quality beechwood (Fagus sylvatica) in a thickness that corresponds to the intended width of your contact samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":40,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e899s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eip02","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2mpdm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"thickness","mutability":"","data":{"error":false,"guid":"66E721B0D41411EB95737B5F69F829D8","id":0,"label":"thickness (of pre-planed plank, will correspond to contact sample's width)","scientificNotation":false,"unit":201,"value":"48.5"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"evo7","text":"Practical note:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"due2","text":"It may be advisable, before a purchase, to enquire whether a supplier regularly stocks beechwood in the specific sorting grade and thickness chosen. In addition, whether it is possible to have blanks for the contact samples cut from the plank by the supplier (cf. step 2.1) may be crucial in choosing a timber shop.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"43fcs","text":"Explanatory comments:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":16,"offset":0,"style":"italic"},{"length":13,"offset":917,"style":"italic"}],"key":"a5l9v","text":"Fagus sylvatica: As the product of a deciduous or, more precisely an angiosperm tree species, beechwood is a hardwood, which by contrast with the softwood produced by most coniferous or gymnosperm trees should be conducive to a quicker and/or more pronounced generation of use-wear traces. In addition, it is noted for its homogeneity and, although not a true sapwood species due to the facultative formation of false ('red') heartwood in older trees, traded beechwood is typically sapwood (cf. comment on wood quality below). The sapwood or alburnum is the physiologically active outer part of a living tree’s wood below the bark, facilitating, amongst others, the transport of water, whereas the heartwood does not contain living cells and has undergone chemical and structural changes such as the formation of tyloses, which block water transport. This means that the wood of heartwood species such, e.g., as oak (Quercus robur) is less suited to the 'forced re-hydration' that is a crucial part of this protocol (cf. step 3). While beech first came to prominence in the post-glacial woods of Central Europe in the Subboreal climatic phase and in many regions was or came to be the dominant forest tree in the Bronze Age, it is also the most common deciduous tree species in considerable parts of Europe today, including Germany, where it accounts for around 17.5 % of the annual wood harvest, which means a consistent and reliable supply. A more extensive discussion of the practical and archaeological reasons for the choice of beechwood as a contact material is presented elsewhere (cf. reference below).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"64te","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"9vl7l","text":"wood quality: A higher quality, as indicated by the sorting grade of the procured wood, will mean a lower number of faults, such as e.g. knots, in the wood; in the specific case of beechwood, false 'red' heartwood is also eliminated from higher sorting grades. This means less variation from one contact sample to the next and thus a stronger control of variables in an experimental context. For our current work, we chose the sorting grade ‘Superior’ of Pollmeier Massivholz GmbH \u0026 Co.KG, i.e. the highest quality of sawn timber offered by a major German specialist beechwood supplier. This closely corresponds to the ‘FAS’ grade as defined in the United States by the National Hardwood Lumber Association.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"50o98","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":39,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"45ac3","text":"plank thickness / contact sample width: Our experiments currently use bronze axe replicas of a blade length of approx. 53 mm (variation from 52.2 mm to 54.1 mm across 9 specimens); the plank chosen was traded at a nominal thickness of 52 mm, corresponding to 48.5 mm actual pre-planed thickness. Using contact samples of a width slightly below the blade length allows for contact between sample and contact sample across almost the entire length of the blade while minimizing the risk of leaving uncut 'baulks' at the edge of the contact sample, where the heel or toe of the axe bit may possibly get caught in rig-based experiments with high positional repeatability.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Ulrich Thaler","can_edit":1,"date":"1631114820","doi":null,"guid":"CD3D41A9D8D911EB84580A58A9FEAC02","id":1157,"journal":"Paper presented in session 300 of the 27th Annual Meeting of the European Association of Archaeologists","protocol_id":null,"title":"Consistency is a beech – on socketed axes, experimental control and ligneous contact materials"}}}}

note:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a106q","text":"With a view to the grain of the wood, the long axis of the contact samples should run parallel to (not across) the long axis of the plank. Given the likely dimensions of the plank, in most cases it will be impractical to perform this step in an experimental lab and results may be less consistent than desired; hence, it will be preferable to choose a supplier that also provides the service of cutting the blanks (and no tools for this task are listed in the materials section of this protocol).","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"3eall","text":"Explanatory comment:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"30eb9","text":"We have obtained 18 contact samples from, e.g., a single plank of 300 mm width and 3350 mm length, with a moderate amount of cut-offs. Given a contact sample length of 500 mm and a height of 80 mm, this means that 6 × 3 samples were cut from the plank, with 6 × 500 mm = 3000 mm \u003c 3350 mm and 3 × 80 mm = 240 mm \u003c 300 mm. A yet better fit seems possible since the width of traded planks varies and different standard lengths of 2450 mm and, more importantly, 3050 mm are also available; but material loss from cutting needs to be allowed for and it may not be possible to realize the potential better fit with planks of the latter length.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

The rods' diameter of 12 mm offers, in relation to the 14 mm diameter of the drill-holes, a good compromise between secure fastening and ease of mounting and dismounting of the contact sample.","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{}}},"6":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"6a705","text":"Explanatory comment:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3tkdm","text":"The contact samples prepared in accordance with the present protocol are routinely used with a meachnical rig for use-wear experiments with bronze axe replicas. Inspired by traditional hammer mills, the rig has the axe replica 'hafted' on a long lever mounted on a horizontal axle, meaning the axe head only travels along an arc in a single vertical plane. As a consequence, it is necessary, in order to simulate alternate forehand and backhand strokes and the incremental widening of a notch typical of tree-felling or bucking, to reposition the contact sample relative to the axe head. The latter is achieved through a sample holder rotating on two axes and allowing a linear offset along a third one. Along with the force of impacts, the mobility of the holder necessitates a secure fastening of contact samples, which is facilitated by two threaded rods on the holder which the drill-holes are intended to receive and on which the contact samples is secured with washers and nuts as well as wooden spacers.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d3b2v","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"uslj","text":"   ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"acbgj","text":"For comparative ('semi-actualistic') trials with handheld bronze axes, a saw-horse has been fitted with wooden brackets to hold the standard-sized contact samples. note:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4snnl","text":"The use of a vaccum chamber, as detailed here, considerably speeds up the sorption and But any sort of 'soaking bath' in which wooden contact samples are weighed down until they have largely or completely lost their buoyancy can achieve the same effect.","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"3c7q7","text":"Explanatory comments:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"1igv4","text":"Moisture content: The moisture content (MC) of wood fundamentally influences its physical and mechanical properties and thus is of crucial importance when wood serves as a contact material in use-wear studies. Expressed as a percentage, it is the ratio of the mass of water to the ovendry mass of wood, i.e.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":24,"offset":0,"style":"italic"},{"length":5,"offset":6,"style":"sub"},{"length":4,"offset":13,"style":"sub"}],"key":"6loai","text":"MC = mwater/mwood × 100% ","type":"align-center"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c9k00","text":"For practical purposes, it can be calculated by comparing the wet and dry mass of a given piece of wood, i.e.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":30,"offset":0,"style":"italic"},{"length":3,"offset":7,"style":"sub"},{"length":3,"offset":14,"style":"sub"},{"length":3,"offset":20,"style":"sub"}],"key":"3lf3r","text":"MC = (mwet - mdry)/mdry × 100%","type":"align-center"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4f6sc","text":"The moisture content of green wood can vary considerably, not only between species, but also within a given tree, and ranges from ca. 30% to above 200%.","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8qeh1","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":23,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"39k6o","text":"Fibre saturation point: Moisture can be held in wood either through sorption, i.e. as water bound in the cell walls, or through absorption, i.e. as liquid water or vapour contained in cell lumina or cavities. The moisture content at which, in principle, the cell walls are fully saturated, but no free water is as yet found is referred to as the fibre saturation point (FSP). With some variation, it typically lies at about 30% and is, crucially for present purposes, considered as the point ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cah1d","text":"from which on additional moisture will not change the physical and mechanical properties of wood.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"4":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Samuel V. Glass, Samuel L. Zelinka","can_edit":1,"date":"1270123920","doi":null,"guid":"77D80270D41C11EB95737B5F69F829D8","id":1154,"journal":"In: Wood Handbook. Wood as an Engineering Material (Centennial Edition), pp. 4-1–4-19","protocol_id":null,"title":"Moisture Relations and Physical Properties of Wood"}},"5":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":66,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":66,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"8dc0s","text":"Side-note on alternative approach for contact sample conditioning:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bcs79","text":"Wood stored in a stable atmosphere, i.e. in air of a given relative humidity and temperature (rather than under water), will attain, over time, a stable moisture content specific to those atmospheric conditions; this is called the equilibrium moisture content (EMC). Since a moisture content of 12%, the equilibrium moisture content in standard climatic conditions of 20°C and 65% RH, is a common reference value for the determination of physical and mechanical characteristics of wood, this was explored as an alternative approach for conditioning wooden contact samples for use-wear experiments. Preliminary results in trials with bronze axe replicas were not especially encouraging, with the higher 'resistance' the comparatively dry wood offered to the replicas leading to relatively rapid blunting. The approach may have advantages, however, in the context of other use-wear experiments and may still deserve re-visiting for further studies with bronze axe replicas.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"75s47","text":"Priming vacuum pump","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1g0fp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dlfl","text":"after ensuring that the gas ballast valve of the vacuum pump is open and the valve connecting the pump to the vacuum chamber is closed, start the vacuum pump and leave to idle for 20 minutes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a5vmj","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8h5hk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bio5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3k7dt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":1200,"guid":"0D222EE0D42311EB95737B5F69F829D8","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":20,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"djt36","text":"Explanatory comment:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7bmbi","text":"When pumping atmospheric air in a  vacuum system, the pumped air will invariably contain some water vapour. As there is a water immersion tank, i.e. the soaking vat (cf. step 3.3), contained in the vacuum chamber of this experimental setup, this effect is enhanced due to an increasing vacuum which converts the liquid phase into a gas phase to contribute to the overall contamination. During the compression process in the pump, this water vapour will condense. Failure to remove it will form a contaminant in the sealing oil, prevent the pump from achieving its optimum vacuum pressure and will ultimately be detrimental to the pump itself. A gas ballast valve incorporated into the system will allow a flow of ballast gas (here: air) into the final part of the compression cycle of a mechanical, oil sealed vacuum pump. It allows the vapour to be expelled without condensation and resulting contamination of the sealing oil but pumping with an open gas-ballast valve will affect the ultimate pressure of the pump. To further reduce the harmful effects of condensate formation in the pump, it is allowed to pump against a closed chamber evacuation valve for 20 minutes with an opened gas-ballast valve prior to opening the chamber valve to evacuate the chamber. This way the increased operating temperature of both oil and pump will decrease the formation of condensate. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4fusk","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

note :","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6d9fg","text":"Contact samples should be used soon after conditioning, i.e. typically on the same day, since storage may effect the moisture content (depending on conditions) and the wet wood can be prone to fungal growth. This means that the number of contact samples in any conditioning cycle should be adjusted to the needs of the next days experiments and will tend to be low. With two stickers (cf. explanatory comment below) of a length slightly less than the width of the vat needed for every layer of contact samples in the stack, plus an additional two for placing the weight, a total of four stickers will usually suffice, but it may be helpful to keep spares.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

It also calculates 'target weights' for the conditioning process, based on the pre-conditioning weight and the (hypothetical) assumption that a moisture content of 35% be reached starting from a pre-conditioning moisture content of 0%. Since the latter corresponds to fully ovendry wood, the 'target weight' will be an over-estimate for any contact sample already containing any moisture, meaning that if the calculated 'target weight' is reached or surpassed, a moisture content above 35% and thus well above fibre saturation point can be safely assumed.","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1bmgg","text":"  ","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"asko","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"E7E8C010D8B611EB8D7F39081E65467B","id":118544,"nestedSelector":"step-4B8B8CC0D42411EB95737B5F69F829D8-nested-draft-72q8n","original_name":"contact-sample-log_template_2021-06-28.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/dv2sbg497.xlsx"},"mutability":"","type":"file"}}}}}}

below, step 6) in terms of accuracy, but is far quicker and does not change the measured moisture content. Besides such general reservations, the Brennenstuhl MD in particular has a measuring range of 5–50% for wood and is thus not suited to exactly determine the moisture levels likely encountered at this point (nor is it, indeed, intended for that purpose by the manufacturer). It is here employed merely to double-check that a moisture content in excess of fibre saturation has been reached. Despite this inherent inaccuracy, a triple measurement (with use of the instrument in three different spots) is recommended to control for intra-sample variation.","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

If the criterion for weight constancy, i.e. a weight change of <1‰, has been reached, the weight change will be highlighted in green.","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"avr86","text":"  ","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3jpa3","text":"","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5neb2","text":"In addition, the end date of weight recording should be recoreded in the main recording template provided with this protocol ("drying-log_template_2021-06-28.xlsx") and the values for weight and moisture content copied to it from the oven-drying template.","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8ngd1","text":"  ","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"53DB1046D8BE11EB92990A58A9FEAC02","id":118549,"nestedSelector":"step-3602E2D0D7EA11EBBD2DEDCB3864EE42-nested-draft-49bqg","original_name":"drying-log_template_2021-06-28.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/dv2xbg497.xlsx"},"mutability":"","type":"file"},"1":{"data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"53DB1105D8BE11EB92990A58A9FEAC02","id":118580,"nestedSelector":"step-3DDE2D00D7E711EBBD2DEDCB3864EE42-nested-draft-7ccrp","original_name":"contact-sample-log_template_2021-06-28.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/dv3wbg497.xlsx"},"mutability":"","type":"file"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8h2km","text":"Calculation of further attributes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpj2f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d58kj","text":"Optionally, further attributes may be calculated at this point.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6no05","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c27cr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"62mes","text":"Practical note:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f1euj","text":"As but one example of further attributes, the main recording template (\"drying-log_template_2021-06-28.xlsx\") will automatically calculate an oven-dry equivalent for the weight(/mass) removed from the contact sample during experimentation (cf. step 4.3). The cuboid form of the samples, with two cylindrical drill-holes, aids further calculations. In particular, it permits the calculation of volume, from which density can be derived. While expansion, shrinkage and warping can be observed throughout the treatment of the contact samples (with moisture contents varying between oven-dry and well above fibre saturation), the fact that contact samples have been cut to specified dimensions at a 'trade-dry' moisture content of approx. 7–9% should allow an operationally reliable approximation of their dry volume.","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fhi8s","text":"  ","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eqigk","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"33A30AB0D8B711EB8D7F39081E65467B","id":118548,"nestedSelector":"step-3A91EE90D7EF11EBBD2DEDCB3864EE42-nested-draft-6no05","original_name":"contact-sample-log_template_2021-06-28.xlsx","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/dv2wbg497.xlsx"},"mutability":"","type":"file"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a7ej6","text":"Storage","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jvdt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3iu3t","text":"archive contact samples alongside samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jc5m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ibak","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"60bea","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqt1m","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"f4ndq","text":"Explanatory comment: ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"51ing","text":"As indicated before (cf. step 5, explanatory comment), the work-traces on the contact samples can be highly informative, even if the use-wear on the sample is the primary source in experimental traceology – as it is in the traceological study of archaeological samples, where the contact material is typically not available for examination. In experimental traceology, contact samples can be examined and hence it is deemed good practice to archive them for future reference. The cuboid shape of the contact samples used in the present protocol allows for easy and efficient (solid-pile) stacking.","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"9AE0ABB0DF3811EBAD53FD8CAFC3CEE2","height":437.6363636363636,"id":196166,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"55je1","text":"Fig. 8: Contact samples prepared and treated in accordance with the present protocol in post-trial storage, shelved between axe handles (left) and roundwood contact samples (right)","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a7boq","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":196,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"51i5j","text":"Despite some warping evident particularly on the left side of the solid-pile stack, the cuboid contact samples are clearly more suited to economizing shelf-space than their roundwood counterparts.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Fig_Shelf.JPG","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f9uibg497.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f9ugbg497.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f9uhbg497.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f9ufbg497.webp","width":580}}}}
